CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 573, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the dimensions of a boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 468, 104]]<|/det|>
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 112, 680, 319]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 332, 533, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 146, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
The student pours a small amount of water into the boiling tube and measures the height \(h_0\) from the bench to the initial water level.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 411, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
\[h_0 = \frac{2.6}{h_0} \quad \text{cm}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** precaution that is taken when measuring the height of the water level to ensure the reading is accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 480, 589, 498]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 605, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The student uses a measuring cylinder graduated in \(\text{cm}^3\) to add a volume of water \(V = 5.0 \text{cm}^3\) to the boiling tube. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 855, 121]]<|/det|> Part of the boiling tube, after the water has been added, is shown full size in Fig. 1.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 141, 670, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 358, 534, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 389, 920, 425]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the new height \(h\) of the water level from the bench. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 406, 920, 425]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 437, 541, 455]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 463, 640, 615]]<|/det|>
\(V/\text {cm}^{3}\)\(h/\text {cm}\)\(H/\text {cm}\)
5.0
10.05.52.9
15.06.74.1
20.08.35.7
25.09.67.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 631, 146, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 920, 682]]<|/det|> For the value of \(V = 5.0 \text{cm}^3\), calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the increase in height \(H\) of the water in the boiling tube. Use the value of \(h_0\) from **(a)**, your value of \(h\) in Table 1.1 and the equation \(H = (h - h_0)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 664, 920, 682]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 594, 91]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / \text{cm}^3\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(H / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 522, 144, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 522, 180, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 522, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 615, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 647, 181, 665]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 647, 616, 665]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(D\), the inside diameter of the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 670, 900, 700]]<|/det|>
Use the equation \(D = \sqrt{\frac{4G}{\pi}}\), where G is numerically equivalent to the gradient in (e)(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 738, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
<form>D = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 738, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Suggest why it was important for the student to add a small volume of water at the start of the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
Another student uses this experiment, with the same apparatus, to measure \(D\) for a small test-tube of diameter approximately \(1.2 \text{cm}\). He adds water in volumes of \(1.0 \text{cm}^3\) at a time. State and explain one reason why this is not an accurate method to use for this test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 301, 922, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 304, 922, 322]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A student performs an experiment on the cooling of water contained in a beaker. He investigates the effect of the colour of the outside surface of the beaker on the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 460, 121]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 420, 152]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered with black card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 457, 167]]<|/det|>
Beaker B is covered with shiny metal foil.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 173, 902, 481]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 495, 532, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 527, 144, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 714, 546]]<|/det|>
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 556, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)  ................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 146, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 588, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
The student pours a volume of \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 181, 654]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** precaution that can be taken to ensure that the temperature reading is as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<form>  ......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 712, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 744, 841, 762]]<|/det|>
He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 775, 574, 793]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the process for beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 576, 89]]<|/det|> Add units to the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 128, 809, 370]]<|/det|>
beaker A
with black card		beaker B
with shiny metal foil
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)
086.085.5
3080.583.5
6076.082.0
9073.080.5
12071.079.5
15069.579.0
18068.578.5
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 146, 405]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 920, 420]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating if the colour of the outside surface of the beaker affects the rate of cooling of the water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 643, 437]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to values from the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 542, 920, 560]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 146, 591]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 572, 180, 591]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 897, 590]]<|/det|> Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) for the water in beaker A during the experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 590, 710, 608]]<|/det|> Use the readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 618, 559, 650]]<|/det|> \[x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 662, 920, 695]]<|/det|> where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 487, 712]]<|/det|> Include the unit for the cooling rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
\(x_{\mathrm{A}} =\) ............................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{\mathrm{B}}\) for the water in beaker B during the experiment. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 119, 559, 149]]<|/det|>
\[x_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 160, 920, 195]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 193, 329, 210]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 253, 920, 272]]<|/det|>
<form>X<sub>B</sub> = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 144, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 285, 181, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 285, 920, 319]]<|/det|>
A student states that the black card is a thermal insulator. He thinks this will affect the result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 332, 623, 351]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 425, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 454, 181, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 454, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Suggest two variables which should be kept the same for the additional experiment so that the comparison with this experiment is fair. Assume that the same type of beaker is used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 516, 917, 536]]<|/det|>
1. ................................................................

2. ................................................................

<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 656, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
State how the cooling rate of beaker A from the additional experiment is likely to compare with \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\) from (d)(i) if the student's theory is correct. Explain your answer.

statement ................................................................

explanation ................................................................

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 655, 89]]<|/det|>
Some students investigate circuits containing resistors in parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 433, 104]]<|/det|>
They use the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 526, 135]]<|/det|>
All numeric answers must have appropriate units.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 160, 707, 358]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 420, 532, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 144, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, complete the circuit to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the parallel combination of resistors P and Q. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 497, 146, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
A student measures the potential difference \(V\) across the parallel combination of resistors P and Q and measures the current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 552, 548]]<|/det|>
The readings are shown in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3.

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 199, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
The student connects the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across resistor S. The reading is shown in Fig. 3.4.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 593, 920, 615]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 185, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A student changes the circuit and uses a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 757, 121]]<|/det|>
In the space provided, draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Mark with an X on Fig. 3.1 where a variable resistor is connected to control the current in resistor S without affecting the resistance of either of the parallel branches. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 181, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
The current in the circuit can be controlled by connecting a range of different resistors in place of resistors P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
State one disadvantage of this method instead of using a variable resistor to control the current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 440, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 826, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of temperature on the bounce height of a squash ball. A squash ball is a hollow rubber ball approximately \(4\mathrm{cm}\) in diameter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the bounce height of the ball changes as the temperature of the ball rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 398, 183]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 378, 198]]<|/det|>
· a selection of squash balls

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 479, 214]]<|/det|>
· standard laboratory heating equipment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 594, 229]]<|/det|>
· a beaker large enough for the squash ball to fit inside

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 344, 245]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 324, 276]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 457, 306]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions to ensure reliable results (you may draw a diagram below if it helps to explain your plan)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 507, 384]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 834, 431]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 603, 462]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
